description: From Middle English kne, from Old English cnƒìow, from Proto-West Germanic *kneu, from Proto-Germanic *knewƒÖ, from Proto-Indo-European *«µn√©w-o-m, a thematic derivative of *«µ√≥nu.

See also Low German Knee, Dutch knie, German Knie, Danish kn√¶, Norwegian kne, Swedish kn√§; also Hittite íÑÄíâ° (genu), Latin gen≈´, Tocharian A kanwe·πÉ (dual), Tocharian B kenƒ´, Ancient Greek Œ≥œåŒΩœÖ (g√≥nu, ‚Äúknee‚Äù), Œ≥œâŒΩŒØŒ± (g≈çn√≠a, ‚Äúcorner, angle‚Äù), Welsh glin (‚Äúknee‚Äù), Old Armenian ’Æ’∏÷Ç’∂÷Ä (cunr), Avestan ê¨≤ê¨•ê¨éê¨®‚Äé (≈ænum), Sanskrit ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Å (jƒÅÃÅnu).
The obsolete plural kneen is from Middle English kneen, knen, kneon, kneuwene.

nouns.description: knee (plural knees or (obsolete or dialectal) kneen)

entries.meaning: In humans, the joint or the region of the joint in the middle part of the leg between the thigh and the shank.
examples: Penny was wearing a miniskirt, so she skinned her exposed knees when she fell.

entries.meaning: In the horse and allied animals, the carpal joint, corresponding to the wrist in humans.
The part of a garment that covers the knee.
(shipbuilding) A piece of timber or metal formed with an angle somewhat in the shape of the human knee when bent.
examples: Deck beams were supported by hanging knees, triangular pieces of wood typically found underneath the timbers they are designed to support, but in this case found above them.

entries.meaning: (with the verb "take") An act of kneeling on one knee, typically to acknowledge an injury or sacrifice or otherwise to show respect.
examples: After Kyle went down hard on the ice, both teams took a knee as he was carried off on a stretcher.

entries.meaning: (archaic) An act of kneeling, especially to show respect or courtesy.
examples: [‚Ä¶]  and he made a knee to the Caesar of Patna, giving that man all honour due to him.

entries.meaning: Any knee-shaped item or sharp angle in a line; an inflection point.
A blow made with the knee; a kneeing.
examples: Tante was groggy but not quite out so Winnie gave him a knee to the jaw that Rose had shown her, and that was enough. He slumped like a rag-doll to the floor.

verbs.description: knee (third-person singular simple present knees, present participle kneeing, simple past and past participle kneed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To poke or strike with the knee.
examples: When I blocked her from leaving, she kneed me in the groin.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To move on the knees; to use the knees to move.
